title-group.article-title: Impact of the Heterogeneity in Market Power on the Relationship Between Risk Taking and Competition: Case of the Chilean Banking Sector

abstract.p: Until the end of the 1990s, the existence of a negative relationship between banking competition and stability was generally accepted in the economic literature. Since then, a new point of view has emerged questioning this relationship and instead argues about the existence of a positive relationship between these two variables. This paper studies the impact of the heterogeneity in market power on this relationship through the case of the Chilean banking sector. The results indicate that this kind of heterogeneity can play an important role in the relationship between risk taking and competition.

ref.mixed-citation: The Chilean Superintendency of Banks and Financial Institutions (for details, see its www .sbif.cl) has declared its objective to be to protect the security of the financial system's creditors as well as the system's competition and stability.

The C5 index measures the market share deposits of the five biggest banks. In particular, the main five Chilean banks in the period in analysis are Santander-Chile bank, Bank of Credit and Investments (BCI), Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria bank (BBVA), Bank of Chile, and Bank of the State of Chile. The Herfindahl-Hirschman index is a measure of the size of all firms in relation to the industry. These indexes were elaborated using date from the Chilean Superintendency of Banks and Financial Institutions (www.sbif.cl).
We also used time-dummies without significant changes in the results.
We use other variables for the economic cycle, such as the unemployment rate and the inflation rate, without significant changes in our results.
This ratio is used by the Chilean Superintendency of Banks and Financial Institutions as an efficiency measure.

Since a bank's market share can be taken as a proxy for competition (though there is still discussion about this issue), we also use the banks' liabilities with respect to the total liabilities of the banking sector, without significant changes.

The fixed effect approach of this panel data is more efficient than the random effect approach according to the Hausman test. Problems with contemporary correlation, heteroskedasticity, and serial self-correlation were detected and subsequently resolved through the robust estimation of the variance-covariance matrix.

We used a mixture of different lags as instruments without significant changes.
